rubric:
Rubric for Laughter essay:

"6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliche00e9s, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write a bad essay that has many spelling mistakes, is completely off-topic and disorganized, have English and punctuation errors, has the style of a first or second grader's writing, and is overall poor.
essay:
Once upon a time, my frend and I went to the zoo. We saw lots of aminals like monkeys and tigers. But then I fll down and my frend laughed at me. It was not nice! But then I got up and we saw more anmials. I like giraffe best. They have long nek. My frend laffed again when I try to touch the giraffe. It was so funny.

After we go home, my frend and I played outside. We had lot of fun in the sun. I had a ball and we kicked it around. My frend kicked the ball to me and I tripped over it. My frend laughed so much that he started to cry. It was silly!

Then we go back inside and eat lunch. My mom made us grilled cheese sandwhiches. I ate mine so fast that I chocked on it. My frend laffed so hard that milk came out his nose. It was gross but also funny. 

In the end, laffter is important. It helps us bond and have fun. Even though my frend laffed at me a lot, I know he is just joking. We have fun together und play all the time. Laughter is good for our frendship. The end!

prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Resilience is a trait that we often don't truly appreciate until we are faced with a challenge that tests our strength and determination. When my best friend Sarah was diagnosed with a serious illness last year, I saw firsthand just how resilient she truly was.

Sarah had always been the type of person who faced challenges head-on, with a positive attitude and a determination to overcome whatever obstacles stood in her way. So when she received the devastating news that she had cancer, I knew that she would approach this adversity with the same resilience and courage that she approached everything else in her life.

Despite the daunting road that lay ahead of her, Sarah never wavered in her determination to beat the illness. She underwent grueling treatments with grace and strength, never once complaining or feeling sorry for herself. Even on her worst days, when the pain was unbearable and the future seemed uncertain, she remained optimistic and focused on the goal of getting better.

As Sarah's friend, I watched in awe as she faced each setback with a resilience that I had never seen before. She refused to let the illness define her or dictate her future. Instead, she found ways to stay strong, flexible, and hopeful, even when the odds seemed stacked against her.

Through it all, Sarah never lost her sense of humor or her ability to find joy in the simple things in life. She drew strength from the love and support of her friends and family, and she never lost sight of the light at the end of the tunnel. Despite the challenges she faced, Sarah continued to move forward with grace and dignity, inspiring everyone around her with her unwavering resilience.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. After months of treatment and countless setbacks, she emerged victorious, cancer-free and stronger than ever. Her journey was not an easy one, but it was a testament to the power of resilience in the face of adversity.

Seeing Sarah's journey taught me the true meaning of resilience. It is not about avoiding challenges or setbacks, but about facing them head-on with strength, determination, and a positive attitude. Sarah's story is a reminder that no matter how difficult the road may be, resilience can help us overcome even the toughest of obstacles and emerge stronger on the other side.

One time my friend Jane showed a lot of resilence. We were on the playground and she tripped and fell and scraped her knee really bad. She was crying and hurt but she didnt give up. She got up and wiped her tears and said she would be okay. She didnt let the pain stop her from having fun. She kept playing with us and didnt let the accident ruin her day. I was really proud of her for being so strong.

Resilence is important because it helps us keep going even when things get tough. Like when my dog ran away and I was sad, but I didnt give up hope. I kept looking for him and eventually found him. It taught me that even when bad things happen, we can still find a way to be happy again.

In conclusion, being resilent is a good trait to have. It helps us stay strong in the face of challenges and setbacks. I hope we can all be like my friend Jane and never give up no matter what happens.

prompt:
Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Patience is a virtue that not everyone possesses. It requires a great deal of understanding and tolerance to be patient in difficult situations. It is the ability to endure hardships without complaint and to remain calm in the face of adversity. And while it may not always be easy to be patient, the rewards of practicing this virtue are immense.

I remember a time when my best friend Sarah demonstrated incredible patience in a challenging situation. We were on a road trip to visit a friend in another state, and we found ourselves stuck in traffic for hours due to a major accident up ahead. As the minutes turned into hours and the line of cars seemed never-ending, I could feel my frustration building. But Sarah remained calm and collected, choosing to focus on the positives rather than the negatives.

Despite the uncomfortable heat and the loud honking of nearby cars, Sarah started playing some music on the radio and cracking jokes to lighten the mood. She even pulled out some snacks from our cooler and started sharing them with me, making the whole situation more bearable. Her ability to stay composed and optimistic in the face of such a frustrating ordeal was truly inspiring.

I couldn't help but admire Sarah's patience and grace under pressure. While I was ready to explode with anger and impatience, she showed me that it was possible to remain calm and positive even in the most stressful of situations. Her ability to see the bigger picture and not let small inconveniences ruin her mood was a valuable lesson for me.

In conclusion, patience is a valuable trait that not everyone possesses. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure hardships without complaint. My friend Sarah's demonstration of patience during our road trip taught me the importance of remaining calm and positive in challenging situations. It is a virtue that I continue to strive for, knowing that the rewards of practicing patience are truly worth it in the end.

prompt:
Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
essay:
One time, I had to wait a long time for my mom to finish her important meeting. I was so bored and starting to get hungry. But I knew my mom had to work. So, I decided to be patient and wait quietly in the waiting room.

I played with some toys I found in the room. I built a tower out of blocks and pretended it was a castle. I also colored a picture of a dinosaur that was hanging on the wall. It was fun for a little bit, but then I got restless again.

I walked around the room, looking out the big windows. I saw cars driving by and people walking on the street. I wished I could go outside and play. But I knew I had to wait for my mom.

I decided to sit down and read a book I brought with me. It was a story about a brave knight who saved the princess from an evil dragon. I got lost in the story and forgot about how long I had been waiting.

Finally, my mom came out of the meeting. She thanked me for being patient and told me she was proud of me. I smiled and hugged her, happy that I could make her proud.

Being patient was hard, but I knew it was the right thing to do. I learned that sometimes, you have to wait for things to happen. And being patient can make you feel good inside.

The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Laughter has always been an essential element in my relationship with my best friend, Maya. Despite living miles apart, our bond has only grown stronger over the years, thanks in part to our shared sense of humor.

One summer, Maya and I decided to take a road trip to visit some college campuses. As we drove through the scenic countryside, we found ourselves lost in conversation, sharing funny anecdotes and cracking jokes along the way. Our laughter filled the car, making the long journey feel short and enjoyable.

One evening, as we were driving to our next destination, Maya suddenly pointed out a sign for a nearby amusement park. Without hesitation, we decided to make a spontaneous detour and spend the rest of the day riding roller coasters and indulging in sugary treats.

As we waited in line for our first ride, Maya couldn't contain her excitement and started making funny faces at the people around us. I couldn't help but burst into laughter, causing a ripple effect among the other riders in line. Suddenly, we found ourselves surrounded by strangers, all sharing in our joy and laughter.

Throughout the day, Maya and I found ourselves in one hilarious situation after another e2013 from getting stuck on a malfunctioning ride to accidentally spilling ice cream on ourselves. But through it all, we laughed until our stomachs hurt, creating memories that would last a lifetime.

By the end of the day, as we drove back to our hotel, exhausted but elated, Maya turned to me and said, "I'm so grateful to have you as my best friend. Our laughter is the glue that holds us together, no matter how far apart we may be."

In that moment, I realized just how important laughter truly is in any relationship. It has the power to bridge the gap between two people, to create a sense of closeness and camaraderie that transcends physical distance. And in my friendship with Maya, laughter has been the thread that has woven our bond tighter than ever before.

As we continue to navigate life's ups and downs, I know that as long as we can still find reasons to laugh together, our friendship will remain unbreakable. For laughter truly is the shortest distance between two people e2013 a bridge that connects hearts, minds, and souls in a way that nothing else can. And for that, I am forever grateful.

prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
essay:
One time me and my best friend Lily were at recess and we were swinging on the swings. Lily was trying to swing really high and she ended up falling off her swing! I was really worried but she just started laughing and laughing. I couldn't help but giggle too and soon we were both rolling on the ground laughing so hard.

After that, we couldn't stop laughing every time we saw each other. We would just look at each other and burst out laughing, even if nothing was funny. It was like we had our own inside joke that only we understood.

One day, we were in class and our teacher was writing on the board. She accidentally spelled a word wrong and we both looked at each other and started cracking up. Our teacher didn't know what was so funny but we just couldn't stop laughing.

That laughter brought us closer together and made our friendship even stronger. We knew that no matter what happened, we could always count on each other to make us laugh. Laughter really is the best medicine, especially when you can share it with someone you care about.

prompt:
We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write a bad essay that has many spelling mistakes, is completely off-topic and disorganized, have English and punctuation errors, has the style of a first or second grader's writing, and is overall poor.
essay:
One time, me and my friend were playing at the park. We were having so much fun swinging on the swings and going down the slide. Then, my friend told a joke about a chicken crossing the road. I laughed so hard that milk came out of my nose!

It was so funny because the chicken was wearing sunglasses and a hat. We couldn't stop laughing for a long time. It felt good to laugh with my friend because it made me happy.

After we were done laughing, we played some more on the monkey bars and pretended to be superheroes. I was superman and my friend was batman. We saved the park from the evil monkeys who were trying to take over.

Even though we were just kids playing pretend, we had so much fun together. Laughter is important because it brings people together and makes everything better. I love laughing with my friend and I can't wait to do it again. Laughing is the best!

Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
prompt:
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
essay:
Resilience is a quality that is not easily come by, but when demonstrated, it can be truly inspiring. I remember a time when my best friend, Sarah, showed incredible resilience in the face of a major challenge.

It was during our sophomore year of high school when Sarah's family faced financial difficulties. Her parents had lost their jobs due to the economic downturn, and they were struggling to make ends meet. As a result, Sarah had to take on more responsibilities at home, including getting a part-time job to help support her family.

Despite the stress and uncertainty that her family was facing, Sarah remained steadfast and focused. She never complained or let the situation bring her down. Instead, she took on her new responsibilities with determination and a positive attitude. She worked tirelessly at her job, balancing it with her schoolwork and extracurricular activities.

I remember one particularly difficult day when Sarah came to school looking visibly tired and worn out. She had worked a double shift the night before to cover for a sick coworker, and she was running on only a few hours of sleep. But instead of feeling sorry for herself, Sarah simply brushed off her exhaustion and got through the day with a smile on her face.

Through it all, Sarah never lost sight of her goals and dreams. She knew that her family's financial situation was only temporary, and she remained hopeful for the future. She stayed focused on her studies, continued to excel in her extracurricular activities, and never gave up on her dreams of going to college.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. Her family eventually overcame their financial difficulties, and she was able to graduate high school with honors. She went on to attend her dream college on a scholarship, where she continued to excel academically and make a positive impact on those around her.

Sarah's story serves as a reminder that resilience is not just about bouncing back from adversity, but also about staying strong, flexible, and optimistic in the face of challenges. It is a quality that can help us navigate life's ups and downs with grace and determination. And it is a quality that Sarah demonstrated in spades, inspiring all those around her to never give up, no matter how tough the road ahead may seem.

essay:
One time my friend David showed a lot of resilience when he didn't make the basketball team at school. He was really sad at first, but he didn't give up. He kept practicing every day after school and working on his skills.

Even though he wasn't on the team, he still went to every game and cheered on his friends. He didn't let not making the team get him down. Instead, he used it as motivation to work harder and try again next year.

I think David is really strong and brave for not giving up when things got tough. He could have easily just quit and been sad, but he didn't. He stayed positive and focused on getting better.

In the end, David's hard work paid off. The next year, he tried out for the team again and he made it! He was so happy and proud of himself. I was really happy for him too. It just shows that if you keep going and don't give up, you can do anything you set your mind to. David is a great example of resilience and I'm glad to have him as a friend.

The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",

The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
            "1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader.
essay:
One time my friend and I were at the park and we saw a dog chasing a squirrel. It was so funny because the squirrel was running really fast and the dog was barking like crazy. My friend and I couldn't stop laughing at the silly scene.

We tried to catch our breath and calm down, but then we noticed a little kid trying to feed bread to a group of ducks. The ducks were all squawking and flapping their wings, and the kid was chasing after them with the bread. It was so hilarious to watch the chaos unfold.

After that, we sat down on a bench and talked about all the funny things we had just seen. We kept giggling and snickering as we remembered the dog, the squirrel, the ducks, and the kid. It was like we were sharing a secret language of laughter that only we understood.

That day, I learned that laughter really is the shortest distance between two people. It brought my friend and me closer together as we shared in the joy of those silly moments. I realized how important laughter is in a relationship, whether it's a friendship or something more. It creates a bond that can't be broken, no matter how many ducks try to steal your bread.

essay:
One of the most inspiring examples of resilience that I have witnessed was when my best friend, Emily, faced a series of setbacks during her sophomore year of high school. Despite the challenges she encountered, she remained strong, flexible, and optimistic throughout the entire ordeal.

It all started when Emily was diagnosed with a chronic illness that required her to undergo frequent medical treatments and take medication daily. This news was devastating for her, as it meant that she would have to miss a lot of school and extracurricular activities. Despite the physical toll that the illness took on her body, Emily refused to let it define her. She continued to attend classes whenever she could, often participating remotely through video calls with her teachers and classmates.

As if dealing with her illness wasn't challenging enough, Emily also experienced academic setbacks during this time. Due to her frequent absences, she fell behind in her coursework and struggled to keep up with assignments. However, instead of giving up, Emily sought help from her teachers and classmates, working tirelessly to catch up on missed work and improve her grades. She attended tutoring sessions, stayed after school for extra help, and spent countless hours studying at home. Her determination and perseverance paid off, as she was able to raise her grades and finish the semester successfully.

In addition to her health and academic struggles, Emily also faced personal challenges during this time. She felt isolated from her friends and peers, as she missed out on social events and gatherings due to her illness. However, instead of withdrawing further into herself, Emily reached out to her friends and family for support. She confided in them about her struggles and fears, and they rallied around her, offering words of encouragement and comfort.

Despite the numerous obstacles that she faced, Emily never lost hope or gave up. She remained resilient in the face of adversity, always looking for ways to move forward and overcome the challenges that came her way. Her strength, flexibility, and optimism were truly inspiring, and her ability to bounce back from setbacks with grace and determination left a lasting impact on everyone around her.

In conclusion, resilience is a powerful trait that can help us navigate life's challenges with grace and strength. Emily's story is a testament to the importance of staying strong, flexible, and optimistic in the face of adversity. Her ability to bounce back from setbacks and continue moving forward, despite the obstacles in her path, serves as a reminder that we all have the power to overcome adversity and emerge stronger on the other side.

essay:
One day, my friend Sara showed lots of resilience. She had a big spelling test at school, and she was really nervous about it. She studied really hard all week, but when the test came, she forgot how to spell some of the words.

Sara felt really upset and wanted to give up, but instead, she took a deep breath and asked her teacher if she could retake the test. Her teacher said yes, but Sara only had one more chance to get it right.

Sara didn't give up. She studied even harder for the retake, and when the day came, she spelled every word correctly. She was so proud of herself for not giving up and working hard to overcome the challenge.

I was really impressed by Sara's resilience that day. It showed me that even when things get tough, you can still push through and come out stronger on the other side. Sara's determination and positive attitude inspired me to be more resilient too.

essay:
Patience is a quality that not everyone possesses. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure difficult situations without complaining. I have always admired people who demonstrate patience, as I believe it is a key characteristic of true strength and resilience.

One particular incident comes to mind when I witnessed someone I know exhibit remarkable patience. It was during a family vacation to Disneyland, and we were all excited to experience the rides, shows, and meet our favorite characters. However, as luck would have it, we found ourselves stuck in a long line for the most popular ride in the park.

While everyone around us was growing increasingly frustrated and impatient, my aunt remained calm and composed. She kept a smile on her face and entertained us with stories from her childhood, distracting us from the long wait. Despite the scorching sun and endless line, she never once complained or showed any signs of irritation.

As we finally reached the front of the line after what felt like an eternity, I asked my aunt how she managed to stay so patient throughout the ordeal. She simply replied, "Life is full of unexpected delays and obstacles. It's how we choose to react to them that defines our character. Patience is a virtue that helps us navigate through life's challenges with grace and dignity."

Her words stuck with me long after that day. I realized that true patience is not just about waiting for something to happen, but about how we handle the waiting. It is about finding peace in the midst of chaos, and maintaining a positive attitude in the face of adversity.

Since then, I have tried to embody my aunt's example of patience in my own life. I have learned to pause, take a deep breath, and remind myself that everything happens in its own time. Patience has taught me to trust the process, even when the outcome is uncertain.

In conclusion, patience is a valuable trait that can help us navigate through life's challenges with grace and perseverance. Whether it is waiting in line at Disneyland or facing a difficult situation, the ability to remain calm and understanding is a strength that should be celebrated. As I continue to cultivate this virtue in my own life, I am grateful for the lesson my aunt taught me that day.

essay:
Patience is when you wait for something without getting mad. I am patient when I have to wait in line at the store or when my little brother is taking a long time to tie his shoes. Sometimes it's hard to be patient, but it's important to be kind and understanding.

One time, my mom showed a lot of patience. She had to wait for a long time at the doctor's office. We were sitting in the waiting room for what felt like forever. I was getting bored and fidgety, but my mom just sat there calmly reading a book. She didn't complain or get mad, even though we had been waiting for a really long time.

I asked her how she could be so patient, and she told me that sometimes you just have to accept that things take time. She said that getting mad wouldn't make the wait any shorter, so it was better to be patient and make the best of the situation.

Seeing my mom be so patient really taught me a lesson. It made me realize that patience is a good quality to have. It helps you stay calm and keep a positive attitude, even when things aren't going your way.

So now, whenever I have to wait for something, I try to remember my mom's example and be patient. It's not always easy, but I know that being patient is the right thing to do. It makes me feel like a better person, and it helps me handle difficult situations with grace.

Being patient might be hard sometimes, but it's worth it in the end. It helps you stay calm and understanding, even when things are tough. I'm glad I learned about patience from my mom, and I'll always try to be patient in everything I do.

An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
            "1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader.
essay:
Laughter truly has a way of bringing people closer together. I experienced this firsthand during a family vacation to the beach last summer. 

My parents, my younger sister, and I decided to take a break from our busy lives and spend a week relaxing by the ocean. It was the perfect opportunity for us to unwind and bond as a family. 

One day, we decided to rent paddleboards and go out into the water. My dad, who likes to think of himself as a pro at all water sports, was the first one to get on his board. He confidently stood up and started paddling away, but within seconds, he lost his balance and fell face-first into the water. 

My sister and I burst out laughing at the sight of our dad flailing around in the water, trying to get back on his paddleboard. Even my mom couldn't contain her laughter as she attempted to rescue him. 

Despite the initial embarrassment, my dad couldn't help but join in on the laughter. We spent the rest of the afternoon sharing stories and jokes, creating memories that we would cherish for years to come. 

That day at the beach taught me the importance of laughter in fostering strong relationships. It allowed us to let go of our inhibitions and connect on a deeper level. Laughter truly is the shortest distance between two people, breaking down barriers and bringing us closer together.

essay:
Once upon a time, me and my best friend Sarah had a sleepover at her house. We were having so much fun playing games and talking about all kinds of stuff. Then, we decided to make some popcorn and watch a funny movie.

The movie was so hilarious! We couldn't stop laughing at all the silly jokes and funny scenes. At one point, Sarah accidentally spilled her drink all over herself and we both started cracking up. We were laughing so hard that we couldn't breathe!

After the movie was over, we were still giggling about how messy Sarah got. We decided to have a dance party in her living room and we were busting out all kinds of silly dance moves. We were laughing so much that our stomachs hurt!

Before we knew it, it was getting late and we had to go to bed. As we lay in our sleeping bags, we couldn't stop laughing about all the fun we had that night. It was the best sleepover ever!

The next morning, we woke up with smiles on our faces, still remembering all the laughter from the night before. We knew that no matter what, we would always have each other to share funny moments with. Laughter truly is the best medicine for any friendship!

I like to play with my friends at recess. We run around and play tag. One time, my friend Sally fell down and she got mud on her pants. It was really funny because she looked silly with mud on her butt.

We laughed so much that our teacher had to tell us to be quiet. But we couldn't stop laughing. Then, our teacher slipped on a banana peel and fell down too! We laughed even more because she looked even sillier with banana on her butt.

After that, we all had to go to the principal's office. We couldn't stop giggling and the principal was very mad at us. We had to promise not to laugh anymore, but it was so hard because everything seemed so funny.

In the end, we all got detention for laughing too much. But it was worth it because I had so much fun with my friends. Laughter is really important in a relationship because it brings people together and makes everything more fun. I can't wait to laugh with my friends again tomorrow.

essay:
Resilience is a quality that is often tested in times of adversity. It is the ability to bounce back from challenges and setbacks, and to remain strong and optimistic in the face of difficulties. I have seen this quality demonstrated by my friend, Sarah, in a moment of crisis that tested her resilience.

Last year, Sarah was faced with a major setback when she lost her job unexpectedly. She had been working at the same company for several years and had built her career there. Losing her job was a huge blow to her self-esteem and confidence. However, instead of giving up or feeling sorry for herself, Sarah chose to see this setback as an opportunity for growth and change.

Sarah spent the first few days after losing her job feeling down and uncertain about the future. But soon, she picked herself up and started looking for new job opportunities. She updated her resume, reached out to her network for job leads, and went on multiple interviews. Despite facing rejection and disappointment along the way, Sarah remained determined and focused on finding a new job.

After several weeks of searching, Sarah finally landed a new job in a different field. While the job was not exactly what she had envisioned for herself, Sarah saw it as a stepping stone towards her long-term career goals. She embraced the opportunity with enthusiasm and worked hard to excel in her new role.

Sarah's resilience in the face of adversity was truly inspiring to me. Despite the challenges she faced, she remained strong, flexible, and optimistic throughout the process. She did not let the setback define her or hold her back from pursuing her goals. Instead, she used it as a learning experience and a chance for personal growth.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. She not only found a new job but also gained a sense of confidence and resilience that will serve her well in any future challenges that come her way. Through her example, Sarah has taught me the importance of staying strong and hopeful in the face of adversity, and never giving up on my dreams.

I was so proud of Sarah for showing resilience and not letting one bad grade bring her down. She proved that if you keep trying and stay strong, you can overcome any challenge that comes your way.

essay:
Patience is a virtue that is often overlooked in today's fast-paced world. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure difficult situations without complaint. I have always admired those who possess this quality, as it is not always easy to remain calm and composed in the face of adversity.

One particular instance that comes to mind when thinking about patience is when my best friend, Sarah, demonstrated an extraordinary amount of patience in a challenging situation. We had planned a weekend getaway to the mountains, and everything seemed to be going smoothly until we arrived at our cabin and realized that the booking had been mixed up. The cabin we had reserved was double-booked, and there was no other available accommodation in the area due to a local festival taking place.

While I was starting to panic and frantically search for alternative options, Sarah remained surprisingly calm. She assured me that everything would work out and suggested that we explore the town while we figured out a solution. Despite the setbacks, she kept a positive attitude and focused on making the most of our time together.

After a few hours of searching, we stumbled upon a cozy bed and breakfast that had a last-minute cancellation. Sarah's patience and unwavering optimism had paid off, and we ended up having a wonderful weekend despite the initial setbacks. Reflecting on this experience, I realized the power of patience and how it can turn a stressful situation into a memorable adventure.

Patience is not always easy to practice, especially in challenging circumstances. However, it is a valuable trait that can lead to better outcomes and stronger relationships. I learned a valuable lesson from Sarah that day about the importance of remaining patient and optimistic, even when things don't go according to plan. I strive to embody her grace under pressure and approach every situation with a calm and patient mindset.

One day, my friend Sara showed me what it means to be patient.

Sara and I were playing in the park when we saw a little bird with a broken wing. I wanted to help it right away, but Sara told me we needed to be patient. She said that rushing things might make the bird even more scared.

So we sat quietly next to the bird, talking softly to it to try and keep it calm. Sara told me that sometimes, things just take time and we have to be patient and wait for the right moment.

After a while, the bird stopped shivering and started to look less scared. Sara slowly reached out her hand and gently picked up the bird. We took it to a wildlife rescue center and they said they could help it.

Thanks to Sara's patience, the bird was able to get the help it needed. I learned that sometimes, being patient and understanding can make a big difference. Patience is a really important quality to have.

The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Laughter truly is a universal language that has the power to bring people closer together. I remember a time when laughter played a significant role in deepening the bond between my friends and me.

It was a warm summer day, and my friends and I had decided to go on a hiking trip to a nearby mountain. As we began our ascent, we were full of energy and excitement. However, as the sun beat down on us and the steep trail seemed never-ending, exhaustion started to set in. We were hot, sweaty, and starting to feel the strain on our muscles.

Despite the challenging circumstances, we found moments of levity that helped to lift our spirits. Whether it was a funny joke, a silly story, or a spontaneous burst of laughter, we were able to find joy even in the midst of physical discomfort. Our laughter became a coping mechanism, a way to alleviate the stress and fatigue that we were feeling.

One particular moment stands out in my memory. As we reached a particularly steep incline, one of my friends tripped on a loose rock and stumbled forward. In that split second, the tension and seriousness of the situation dissolved as we all burst out laughing. My friend, although slightly embarrassed, couldn't help but join in the laughter. It was a moment of pure, unbridled joy that brought us all together in a shared experience of amusement.

Through that shared laughter, we were able to forge a stronger connection with one another. It created a sense of camaraderie and solidarity that made the rest of the hike feel more manageable. We were no longer just individuals struggling with the physical demands of the mountain; we were a team, supporting and encouraging each other every step of the way.

As we reached the summit and took in the breathtaking view before us, I realized that it was our shared laughter that had carried us through the challenges of the hike. It had brought us closer together and strengthened our bond as friends. In that moment, I understood the true power of laughter in fostering relationships and creating lasting memories.

In conclusion, laughter is indeed a crucial element in any relationship. It has the ability to break down barriers, alleviate tension, and bring people closer together. My hiking trip with my friends taught me that laughter can turn even the most difficult situations into moments of joy and connection. I will always cherish the memories of that day and the laughter that filled our hearts along the way.

essay:
One time me and my friend Sarah were at the park playing tag. Sarah accidentally tripped over a rock and fell down. At first I was worried, but then she started laughing really hard. I couldn't help but laugh too, even though she was a little bit hurt. 

We both sat on the ground laughing until our stomachs hurt. It was funny because Sarah's laugh was so loud and contagious. We forgot all about the fall and just enjoyed the moment. 

After we were done laughing, we helped each other up and continued playing. From then on, whenever we remembered that day, we would start laughing all over again. Laughter really did bring us closer together. 

That day taught me that even in tough times, laughter can make everything better. I'm glad to have a friend like Sarah who can always make me laugh, no matter what.

essay:
Once upon a time, my dog went to the moon. He flew up in a rocket ship and saw lots of aliens. The aliens were very silly and they made my dog laugh a lot. They told jokes and did cartwheels. My dog barked and wagged his tail. 

Then, my dog came back to Earth and told me all about his trip. He said, "Woof woof, I saw funny aliens on the moon!" I laughed and laughed because my dog's story was so silly. We rolled on the floor laughing together. It was a very fun time. 

After that, my dog and I were even closer because we shared this funny experience. Laughter really does bring people (and dogs) together. I love my dog and I love to laugh. The end.

prompt: Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.
rubric:
Rubric for Resilience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
essay:
Resilience is a key trait that can help individuals overcome challenges and setbacks in life. It is the ability to stay strong, flexible, and optimistic even in the face of adversity. I have personally witnessed a great example of resilience in my older sister, Sarah.

A few years ago, Sarah faced a major setback in her academic career. She had been working hard towards her goal of becoming a doctor, studying long hours, and doing well in her courses. However, during her second year of medical school, she failed a crucial exam that threatened her chances of continuing in the program. This was a devastating blow to Sarah, who had always been a high-achieving student.

Instead of giving up or letting the setback define her, Sarah showed incredible resilience. She took the time to reflect on what went wrong, seeking advice from teachers and mentors on how to improve. She developed a new study plan, seeking out additional resources and support to help her succeed. Despite feeling discouraged and disappointed, she continued to push forward, staying focused on her goal of becoming a doctor.

It was not an easy road for Sarah. She faced many challenges and setbacks along the way, but she never lost sight of her goal. Through hard work, dedication, and perseverance, she was able to overcome her academic struggles and eventually graduate from medical school. Today, she is a successful doctor, helping others and making a difference in the world.

Sarah's story is a powerful example of resilience in action. She did not let one setback define her or deter her from pursuing her dreams. Instead, she faced the challenge head-on, using it as an opportunity to grow and improve. Her ability to bounce back from adversity, stay strong, and remain optimistic is truly inspiring.

In conclusion, resilience is an important trait that can help individuals overcome challenges and setbacks in life. Sarah's story is a great example of how resilience can lead to success and fulfillment. By staying strong, flexible, and optimistic, we can overcome any obstacle that comes our way.

essay:
Patience is a quality that is often overlooked, yet it is crucial in navigating life's challenges without becoming overwhelmed. It allows us to remain calm and understanding in the face of adversity, showing tolerance and grace under pressure. 

One of the most memorable examples of patience in my life was when my grandmother fell ill and had to be hospitalized for an extended period of time. This was a difficult time for my family, as we were all worried about her health and well-being. Despite the stress and uncertainty that we were facing, my mother displayed remarkable patience throughout the ordeal. She spent countless hours at the hospital, providing support and comfort to my grandmother, never once complaining or showing signs of frustration. 

I vividly remember one particular day when my grandmother was scheduled for a series of tests that took several hours to complete. My mother sat by her side the entire time, holding her hand and offering words of encouragement. As the hours dragged on, I could see the exhaustion in my mother's eyes, but she never wavered in her patience. She remained composed and focused, determined to stay strong for my grandmother's sake. 

It was during this challenging time that I learned the true meaning of patience. I saw firsthand how it can make a difficult situation more bearable, and how it can bring comfort and solace to those in need. My mother's unwavering patience and compassion inspired me to strive for the same level of understanding and tolerance in my own life. 

In conclusion, patience is a virtue that should not be underestimated. It is a quality that can help us navigate through life's challenges with grace and composure. Whether it is staying calm in the face of adversity or providing support to those in need, patience is a valuable trait that can make a world of difference. My mother's display of patience during my grandmother's illness serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of this quality in our daily lives.

essay:
One time I was at the store with my mom. She had to return something and the lady at the counter was taking a long time. I got bored and wanted to leave but my mom told me to be patient. She said that sometimes things take time and we have to wait. I didn't understand why we had to wait but I tried to be patient.

It felt like we were waiting forever. The lady at the counter was talking on the phone and looking at her computer. I wanted to play on my phone or read a magazine but my mom told me to just be patient.

Finally, after what felt like hours, the lady at the counter finished and we were able to leave. My mom thanked me for being patient and told me that sometimes we have to wait for things to happen.

I learned that being patient is important. Sometimes things don't happen right away and we have to wait. Being patient means not complaining or getting angry. It means understanding that things take time and being tolerant of that.

I am trying to be more patient now. It can be hard sometimes, especially when I want something to happen right away. But I am learning that being patient is a good thing and it can help me in many situations. Just like I was patient at the store, I can be patient in other areas of my life too.

essay:
Once upon a time, there was a girl named Billy. She had to be patient one time when she wanted a cookie but her mom said she had to wait until after dinner. Billy was very upset and mad. She wanted to scream and cry but she knew that she had to be patient.

Billy sat at the table, tapping her feet and folding her arms. She was getting more and more impatient. But then, she remembered what her mom said about being patient and understanding. So, she took a deep breath and decided to wait for the cookie.

After what felt like forever, dinner was finally over. Billy's mom gave her the cookie she had been waiting for. It was the best cookie she had ever tasted. And she was proud of herself for being patient and not throwing a tantrum.

From that day on, Billy remembered the importance of being patient. She learned that sometimes good things come to those who wait. And she knew that being patient would always be worth it in the end.

The end.

The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",

The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Laughter has always been a fundamental aspect of my family's relationships. I remember a particular moment that solidified the importance of laughter in our bond.

It was Thanksgiving Day, and our entire extended family had gathered at my aunt's house for a festive dinner. As we sat around the table, enjoying the delicious meal prepared with love, my cousin decided to share a funny story from his recent trip. His storytelling skills were impeccable, and soon the whole table was roaring with laughter.

In the midst of our laughter, my grandmother, who was known for her dry sense of humor, decided to chime in with a witty comment. This only added fuel to the fire, and soon we were all in tears from laughing so hard. Even my quiet uncle couldn't help but join in, his deep belly laughs echoing through the room.

As the evening wore on, the jokes and stories continued to flow freely. It was in those moments of shared laughter that I felt the true connection between us all. It was as if the laughter was a bridge that brought us closer together, allowing us to let our guards down and simply enjoy each other's company.

By the end of the night, as we bid farewell to our loved ones, the memories of that evening lingered in my mind. It was a reminder of the power of laughter in fostering strong relationships. As the saying goes, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people," and on that Thanksgiving Day, our laughter had brought us all closer than ever before.

essay:
One time, me and my friend Sarah were playing at the park. We were swinging on the swings and talking about funny stuff. Then, Sarah told me a joke and I laughed so hard that I almost fell off the swing!

We kept laughing and making jokes for a long time. It was so much fun to spend time with Sarah and just laugh together. It made our friendship even stronger.

After a while, we decided to go on the slide. Sarah went first and I followed right behind her. As we slid down, we both started laughing again. It was just so silly and we couldn't stop giggling.

Even though we both fell off the slide at the end, we were laughing so hard that we didn't even care. We helped each other up and kept on laughing. It was like nothing could bring us down.

That day at the park was one of the best days ever. Sarah and I learned that laughter really does bring people together and make relationships stronger. I'm so grateful to have a friend like Sarah who can always make me smile and laugh no matter what. Laughter really is the best medicine!

essay:
Patience is a virtue that many people strive to embody in their daily lives. It is the ability to endure difficult situations without getting frustrated or complaining. A patient person remains calm and understanding, even when faced with challenging circumstances.

I have always admired my grandmother for her incredible patience. She never seems to lose her cool, no matter what obstacles come her way. One particular instance that stands out to me is when we were stuck in traffic on our way to a family gathering. It was raining heavily, and the roads were congested with cars.

Despite the stressful situation, my grandmother remained calm and composed. She simply turned on some soothing music and engaged me in a conversation about our plans for the day. Her ability to stay patient and positive in such a frustrating moment left a lasting impression on me.

I asked her how she managed to stay so patient, even in difficult circumstances. She simply smiled and said, "Life is full of unexpected challenges, and getting upset won't change the situation. It's better to focus on what we can control and make the best of it."

Her words resonated with me, and I realized the importance of patience in dealing with life's curveballs. Instead of getting worked up over things that are out of our hands, it is far more beneficial to remain patient and tackle the challenges with grace.

My grandmother's example has inspired me to work on my own patience. I now strive to approach difficult situations with a calm and understanding mindset. I have found that practicing patience has not only made me a more pleasant person to be around but has also helped me navigate through life's ups and downs with greater ease.

In conclusion, patience is a valuable quality that can help us navigate through life's uncertainties with grace and resilience. By emulating my grandmother's unwavering patience, I have learned to approach challenges with a level head and a positive attitude. Patience truly is a virtue worth cultivating.

essay:
One day, my friend Sally was really patient. She wanted to play with her new toy, but she had to wait for her mom to finish cooking dinner. Sally didn't complain or get mad, she just sat and waited quietly. She was understanding and tolerant of the situation.

While she was waiting, Sally helped her mom set the table and even entertained her little brother so her mom could finish cooking. She didn't get frustrated or lose her temper, she just stayed calm and waited for her turn to play with her toy.

When dinner was finally ready, Sally was so happy and grateful. She thanked her mom for the delicious meal and then happily played with her new toy. Her patience paid off and she had a great time playing with it.

I was so impressed by Sally's patience that day. She showed me that being patient is important and that good things come to those who wait. I learned a lot from her and I try to be more patient like she was that day.

essay:
Once upon a time there was a bear named Sally. She liked honey and playing in the woods. One day, Sally was walking in the woods and saw a squirrel. The squirrel was trying to climb a tree, but kept falling down. Sally decided to help the squirrel and waited patiently for it to try again.

The squirrel finally made it up the tree and was very happy. Sally felt good for helping the squirrel and they became friends. They played together every day and had lots of fun.

One day, Sally got very hungry and wanted some honey. She saw a beehive up in a tree and decided to climb up and get some. She waited patiently for the bees to buzz away and then climbed up the tree. But when she reached the hive, the bees came back and stung her. Sally started crying and ran away.

She learned that sometimes it's good to be patient, but also to be careful. And that's why she always asks her friend the squirrel for help when getting honey.

The end.

essay:
Laughter has always played a significant role in my relationship with my best friend, Sarah. We have known each other since we were in elementary school, and our bond has only grown stronger over the years. One particular memory that stands out to me is the time when we went on a road trip together last summer.

It was a spontaneous decision. We decided to pack our bags, jump into my old beat-up car, and just drive with no particular destination in mind. As we hit the open road, we blasted our favorite songs and sang along at the top of our lungs, not caring about who could hear us. Our voices may not have been the most melodious, but the laughter that ensued from our off-key singing was infectious.

Along the way, we encountered all sorts of mishaps - getting lost, running out of gas in the middle of nowhere, and having to rely on a questionable map that Sarah found buried in the glove compartment. Instead of panicking, we laughed it off. Our ability to find humor in even the most stressful situations was what kept us going.

One night, we found ourselves at a roadside diner in a small town. The food was mediocre at best, and the waitress seemed to be having a bad day. Our order was wrong, the milkshake was melted, and the coffee was lukewarm. Rather than getting upset, Sarah started making funny faces behind the waitress's back to make me laugh. Soon enough, we were both giggling uncontrollably, unable to contain our mirth.

That night, as we laid under the stars in a makeshift campsite, we were overcome with a sense of pure joy. The shared experiences, the inside jokes, and the memories we had created together had solidified our friendship even further. Our laughter had bridged the gap between us, making us feel closer than ever before.

As we drove back home, with the sun setting in the distance, I knew that this road trip had been more than just a getaway. It had reaffirmed the importance of laughter in our relationship. The ability to find humor in the mundane, to laugh in the face of adversity, and to share moments of pure joy - these were the foundations of our friendship.

In the end, someone once said that "laughter is the shortest distance between two people." In my case, laughter had not only brought me closer to Sarah but had also strengthened our bond in ways that words could never express. And for that, I am forever grateful.
